node.title: Multiapp Restoring Problem
node.bodyText:
I have two input files below that are a minimal working example of an error I am running into. The error occurs with multiapp restoring. I am a child multiapp that changes the subdomain depending on the current location of the parent multiapp. I have a block restricted auxvariable and auxkernel that changes based on a CoupledVarThresholdElementSubdomainModifier. This is causing the restoring problem. The restore will hang on me for hours even with small meshes until I stop it, so I can't get a backtrace. Using a debugger, I found that within Multiapp.C line 627 the restore is called and it seems to get hung up at SystemBase.C  at line 94 within that for loop. All that occurs in the terminal is
"Restoring Application............................................................................" with the dots ever increasing. Let me know if there are any questions I can answer.
fluid.i
[Mesh]
  [gen]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    xmin = -1.0
    xmax = 3.0
    ymin = 0.0
    ymax = 1.0
    nx = 100
    ny = 25
    elem_type = QUAD4
  []
  [create_subdomain_1]
    type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
    block_id = 1
    input = gen
    bottom_left = ' 0 0 0'
    top_right = '1 1 1 '
  []

[]
[Problem]
  verbose_multiapps = true
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [indicator]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
    initial_condition = 0.0
  []
  [this_is_the_cause]
    block = 0
    [AuxKernel]
      type = ConstantAux
      variable = this_is_the_cause
      block = 0
    []
  []

[]

[Variables]
  [velocity]
    family = LAGRANGE_VEC
  []
  [p]
  []
[]
[Kernels]
  [mass]
    type = INSADMass
    variable = p
  []
  [mass_pspg]
    type = INSADMassPSPG
    variable = p
  []
  [momentum_convection]
    type = INSADMomentumAdvection
    variable = velocity
    block = 0
  []
  [momentum_time]
    type = INSADMomentumTimeDerivative
    variable = velocity
    block = 0
  []
  [momentum_viscous]
    type = INSADMomentumViscous
    variable = velocity
    viscous_form = traction
    block = 0
  []
  [momentum_pressure]
    type = INSADMomentumPressure
    variable = velocity
    pressure = p
    integrate_p_by_parts = true
    block = 0
  []
  [momentum_supg]
    type = INSADMomentumSUPG
    variable = velocity
    velocity = velocity
    block = 0
  []
[]

[BCs]

  [noslip]
    type = ADVectorFunctionDirichletBC
    variable = velocity
    boundary = 'top bottom'
    function_x = 0
    function_y = 0
  []
  [bc]
    type = ADVectorFunctionDirichletBC
    variable = velocity
    boundary = 'left'
    function_x = 10
    function_y = 0
  []
[]
[Materials]
  [mu]
    type = ADGenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'mu rho'
    prop_values = '2.0e-4 0.001225'
  []
  [ins_mat]
    type = INSADTauMaterial
    velocity = velocity
    pressure = p
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = 'NEWTON'
  # Run for 100+ timesteps to reach stey state.

  dt = 1e-2
  end_time = 1
  dtmin = 1.0e-7
  # Note: -snes_ksp_ew seems to le to more nonlinear iterations, which isn't ideal
  # when compute_jacobian() is so expensive for this problem.
  petsc_options = '-snes_converged_reason -ksp_converged_reason'


  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'hypre boomeramg'
  # residual_and_jacobian_together = true
  line_search = 'bt'
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-6
  nl_abs_tol = 2e-7
  nl_max_its = 1
  l_max_its = 1

[]

[Outputs]
  [exo]
    type = Exodus
    file_base = test_results/parent
  []
  print_linear_residuals = false
[]

[UserObjects]
  [indicator]
    type = CoupledVarThresholdElementSubdomainModifier
    coupled_var = indicator
    criterion_type = ABOVE
    threshold = 0.95
    subdomain_id = 1
    complement_subdomain_id = 0
    execute_on = "INITIAL TIMESTEP_BEGIN"
    apply_initial_conditions = false
  []
[]


parent.i
beta = 0.25
gamma = 0.5

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
[]

[Mesh]
  [gen]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    xmin = 0
    ymin = 0
    xmax = 0.2
    ymax = 0.5
    nx = 50
    ny = 150
    elem_type = QUAD4
  []
[]
[Variables]
  [disp_x]
    order = FIRST
  []
  [disp_y]
    order = FIRST
  []
[]

[AuxVariables] # variables that are calculated for output

  [solid_indicator]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
    [AuxKernel]
      type = ConstantAux
      variable = solid_indicator
      value = 0.0
      boundary = 'left right top'
      execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_END'
    []
    initial_condition = 1.0
  []
[]

[Modules/TensorMechanics/DynamicMaster]
  [all]
    # displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
    add_variables = true
    # new_system = true
    incremental = true
    strain = FINITE
    decomposition_method = EigenSolution
    # hht_alpha = 0.25
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [elastic_tensor]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 10000.0
    poissons_ratio = 0.3
    use_displaced_mesh = true
  []
  [stress]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
  []
  [density]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'density'
    prop_values = '1'
    use_displaced_mesh = true
  []
  [constant_stress]
    type = GenericConstantRankTwoTensor
    tensor_values = '100'
    tensor_name = test_tensor
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [hold_x]
    type = DirichletBC
    boundary = bottom
    variable = disp_x
    value = 0
    use_displaced_mesh = true
  []
  [hold_y]
    type = DirichletBC
    boundary = bottom
    variable = disp_y
    value = 0
    use_displaced_mesh = true
  []
  [Pressure]
    [push_left]
      boundary = left
      factor = 100
    []
  []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  []
[]
[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  end_time = 10
  dt = 1e-2
  solve_type = 'NEWTON'
  petsc_options = '-snes_converged_reason -ksp_converged_reason -snes_ksp_ew'
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_type -pc_factor_shift_type -pc_factor_shift_amount'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu       superlu_dist                  NONZERO               1e-15'
  nl_max_its = 2
  l_max_its = 15
  line_search = 'none'
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-5
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-4
  automatic_scaling = true
  fixed_point_max_its = 10
  [TimeIntegrator]
    type = NewmarkBeta
    beta = ${beta}
    gamma = ${gamma}
  []
[]

[Outputs]
  # exodus = true
  [exo]
  type = Exodus
  file_base = test_results/child
  []
  print_linear_residuals = false
  print_linear_converged_reason = false
[]

[MultiApps]
  [fluid_domain]
    type = TransientMultiApp
    execute_on = "INITIAL TIMESTEP_END"
    positions = '0 0 0'
    input_files = fluid.i
    use_displaced_mesh = true
  []
[]

[Transfers]
  [push_indicator]
    type = MultiAppGeometricInterpolationTransfer
    # Transfer from the sub-app from this app
    to_multi_app = fluid_domain
    # The name of the variable in this app
    source_variable = solid_indicator
    # The name of the auxiliary variable in the sub-app
    variable = indicator
    displaced_source_mesh = true
    use_displaced_mesh = true
    num_points = 1
  []
[]
Are you loading this in parallel?

I had this problem in serial too IIRC. I had to use the debugger in serial, but I don't remember how long I would allow the restoring app to go, but during one run at night it must have been stuck for hours, running in parallel.
how are you restoring the app? I dont see a checkpoint parameter in the [Problem] block
Oh, I may be using the incorrect terms. During a multiapp run, when the current timestep fails and the system has to cut the time step, this is when it has the problem above.
I already tested it without the subdomain modifier and without block restricting the aux variable. I believe you need both together for this error to occur.
I'll create an issue and see if we can get someone to work on this
We should make a minimal (non)working example first to attach it to the issue. Do you have one ready?
I can create one now. Is there a simple command in MOOSE input file to cause a nonlinear solve to fail, or do I just need to force it some way.

There is a test object (a Problem) in moose/test that fails on demand. It's called the FailingProblem in moose/test/src/problems and there are examples in moose/test/tests/multiapps/catch_up/failing_sub.i
I can't seem to run it because of A 'FailingProblem' is not a registered object. I am running with --allow-test-objects . Is there something I am missing?

node.title: tests fail after HPC build
node.bodyText: I am building MOOSE on Ubuntu20.04 with newly installed c, g++, gfortran compilers and openmpi wrappers. Because of restrictions at work, I cannot access the inl.gov domain for downloads, but pulled the dist from github and followed the HPC install instructions. After PETSc and libmesh builds I built moose but the test goes wrong: ModuleNotFoundError: No module named "hit". There is also an undefined symbol (_ZSt28__throw_bad_array_new_lengthv). Not sure what is going on here - do I need to install the moose-tools (mamba) to get the test harness work OK? Looks like things go wonky at the various init.py

Hello
installing moose-tools will solve the first one.
the undefined symbol is more problematic. It s likely the compiler suite was not consistent during the whole build process. Or that there are conflicts between several compilers available
Guillaume

@heinono1  what version of python is that build using? I have noticed that sometimes with older python versions the new moose can compile just fine (with little to no error) but then when you try to run the executables then you get hit errors.

If you are building from scratch (that is you are using system compilers), then you will need to install the python-dev package (or maybe it is called python3-dev). Hit requires Python Headers to build. Also, I would refrain from installing the moose-tools package, that package is tied to moose-mpich, which would cause a conflict between your OpenMPI and our package providing MPICH.

Thanks for responses. I am using python 3-9.12 but I did not install the
dev package - I'll do that.

Cheers,
Olle
…

 If you are building from scratch (that is you are using system compilers),
 then you will need to install the python-dev package (or maybe it is called
 python3-dev). Hit requires Python Headers to build. Also, I would refrain

moose-tools). The problem now is that run_tests is looking for python in
/usr/bin/env and that directory is empty. Not sure how to make the test
harness point to the right executables.

/usr/bin/env does not exist? Can you find out where it is?
which env
whatever that returns, I'd like you to make a manual edit to the moose/test/run_tests script. And modify the shebang to match the path returned by the above command.

Hi. /usr/bin/env does exist, and which env returns /usr/bin/env. The edit you suggested seems to work (the tests are running so far).
Thanks!
THere are some crashes because /bin/sh cannot find python

I am betting there are more instances of the shebang in our scripts which is causing you grief. I have not tried this myself, but perhaps you can create your own symlink to python3 and call it python...
which python3
whatever that returns try this:
mkdir ~/bin; cd ~/bin
ln -s `which python3` python
export PATH=~/bin:$PATH
and re-run the tests? Basically we're tricking our scripts into using python which will be mapped to python3.

Yeah I was thinking of doing that....
…
On Tue, Jun 7, 2022 at 9:03 AM Jason Miller ***@***.***> wrote:
 I am betting there are more instances of the shebang in our scripts which
 is causing you grief. I have not tried this myself, but perhaps you can
 create you own symlink to python3 and call it python...

 which python3

 whatever that returns try this:

 mkdir ~/bin; cd ~/bin
 ln -s `which python3` pythonexport PATH=~/bin:$PATH

 and re-run the tests? Basically we're tricking our scripts into using
 python which will be mapped to python3.

node.title: libmesh hashing.h
node.bodyText:
Hi. I am bulding libmesh from a new dist using update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh. The build crashes at ~/contrib/fparser_ad.cc: fatal error: libmesh/hashing.h: No such file or directory #include<libmesh/hashing.h>
The hashing.h file does exist in ./libmesh/inlcude/utils and ./libmesh/include/libmeh (reckoned from the moose directory). It is not clear to me where the build is looking for hashing.h and/or how I should set paths to fix this.

Hello
Could you please attach the config.log in the scripts folder?
Also there is a diagnostics script in moose/scripts you may run to understand the environment
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume. config.log is attached.
config.log

hello
You are partially using the intel oneapi compilers.
We dont support intel compilers anymore as they had a bug, we dropped support for them and we havent come back to trying them.
You also have some gcc compilers active there. Please just unload the modules / remove from the path the intel compilers and stick with GNU compilers and openmpi or similar.
Guillaume

OK, thanks. Will do.
…
-Olle
On Wed, Jun 15, 2022 at 12:37 PM Guillaume Giudicelli < ***@***.***> wrote:
 hello

 You are partially using the intel oneapi compilers.
 We dont support intel compilers anymore as they had a bug, we dropped
 support for them and we havent come back to trying them.

 You also have some gcc compilers active there. Please just unload the

 compilers and openmpi or similar.

 Guillaume

Attached. There s a whole slew of header files that codes in ./contrib/fparser (fparser_ad.cc, as well as header files here looking for header files) cannot find.
config.log

It looks like the problem originates in
./libmesh/contrib/fparser/fparser_ad.cc - it looks for some headerfile that
it cannot find, and that headerfile in turn is looking for other header
files in the same directory
#include <libmesh/some_header_file.h>
…

***@***.***
seems like the same problem @aruybalid was hitting

The problem seems to be a few programs:
./libmesh/contrib/fparser/fparser_ad.cc and ./libmesh/scr/apps/fparser.C
where the paths to header files, which all involve "libmesh/foo.h" or
<libmesh.foo.h>, fail. I am doing the stupid thing to fix this: edit
fparser.C and fparser_ad.cc to look for the header files in the same
directory as the cc or C file - and also edit header files that look for
header files. I copied the relevant header files (which live in ./libmesh I
think) to those two directories. This is obviously a coarse hack but I was
not going to go in end spend more time trying to figure out why the paths
got screwed up.
…
-Olle

 ***@***.***>

Olle Heinonen
***@***.***

So I just pulled a completely fresh dist, made sure I had loaded only GNU
compilers and compatible openmpi, cmake, have python linked to python3.
Now petsc and libmesh both built - no problem (!!). But when I build moose
(cd ./test && make -j 4) I get the message right away "make: python-config:
Command not found". Any ideas???

 directory as the cc or C file - and also edit header files that look for
 header files. I copied the relevant header files (which live in ./libmesh I

 not going to go in end spend more time trying to figure out why the paths
 got screwed up.

 -Olle

node.title: Time dependence from csv file
node.bodyText:
I have a vector field (Hx,Hy,Hz) read in as auxiliary variables using the UO PropertyReadFile, then passed to Function node_Hx, node_Hy, node_Hz using PieceWiseConstantFromCSV, and then seed the (Hx,Hy,Hz) field from that function. What I then need to do is to multiply the field (Hx,Hy,Hz) with a time dependence that cannot be parameterized but is read into a PiecewiseMultilinearfunction that is used to define an auxiliary variable "coil_current". What I'd like to do is then to use an AuxKernel that multiplies "coil_current" (which is the value of a current given by times t from the PiecewiseMultilinear function) with the field (Hx,Hy,Hz) to get a field time-dependent field (Hext_x_time, Hext_y_time,Hext_z_time). I am not sure about the syntax in the AuxKernel. Right now I have
[AuxKernels]
[./Hext_x_time]
type = FunctionAux
variable = Hext_x
function = 'coil_current*node_Hx'
[../]
and similarly for the y and z components. But this is not working (garbled syntax, I think). What is the correct syntax for multiplying together a time-dependent variable (coil_current) with a function (node_Hx)?
Thanks,
Olle
It seems I can use CompositeFunction to multiply the two functions together to generate a new function that can be read in as a FunctionAux. At least running with --check-input throws no error.....

Hello
That is one option. The other is to use the ParsedAux, that should let you multiply two functions together.
Guillaume

Thanks, Guillaume.
…
On Sat, Sep 24, 2022 at 8:43 PM Guillaume Giudicelli < ***@***.***> wrote:
 Hello

 That is one option. The other is to use the ParsedAux, that should let you
 multiply two functions together.

 Guillaume

node.title: Poisson Nernst Planck Model
node.bodyText:
Hello all,
I want to simulate ion transportation through an electrolyte for that I am using Poisson-Nernst-Planck model as shown below.

I have used "soretDiffusion" module to formulate effect of electromigration effect (2nd term in Nernst-Planck equation). Initially linear potential profile is developed and it remains linear and also concentration of cation and anion doesn't change while residual keeps on increasing continuosly.
Plz help me i have to complete project by end of september.
Thank you very much,
Nishant Gaikwad

Hello
I converted your post into a discussions as this is where we usually talk about these subjects
@tonkmr could you please help with this? Seems you are the author of Soret Diffusion in moose
Guillaume
@nishant1785 you should make sure to follow the application development tutorial if you have not. It s very likely you will need to implement some new kernels to achieve this

Thank you very much Guillaume for your response I have followed application
development tutorial.  But I will recheck again.

Nishant Gaikwad-7972836355
M. Tech student
Materials Department
DIAT, DRDO,Girinagar
411025-Pune
…

 likely you will need to implement some new kernels to achieve this

 .
 You are receiving this because you were mentioned.Message ID:
 ***@***.***>
I am happy to look at input files and discuss. You could also try to use the MatDiffusion kernel, where you use a coupled variable. That may be more flexible than SoretDiffusion.

Thank you Michael, instead of MatDiffusion I have used simple diffusion
module because I have to couple variables and I don't know how to do it in
MatDiffusion module. Now input files which I am attaching here are for
non-dimensional formulation of PNP model I mentioned earlier.

*FOR NON-DIMENSIONALISED CASE PERMITTIVITY,DIFFUSIVITY VANISHES FROM
EQUATION HENCE WE ARE ONLY LEFT WITH VARIABLES NO CONSTANTS OR 'EQUATING
ALL CONSTANTS EQUAL TO 1.*
I am doing this for symmetric binary electrolyte meaning* 'CATION VALENCY =
1, ANION VALENCY = -1'.*

I have also attached* boundary** conditions file.*

hi @nishant1785
the file did not paste from your email. You ll have to upload it from the github discussion page.
If I were you I'd list each term in the equation and say how you implemented it.

@GiudGiud  is the provided information enough. Also @tonkmr i have used DIFFUSION KERNEL to code every part of PNP equation (i.e. for voltage/potential difference, diffusion of ions (separate equation for cation and anion) , electromigration effect)

include.zip
src.zip
inputfile.zip
sorry,Here are program files, in bounday condition image C₁ is cation concentration while C₂ is anion concentration. N is flux of ions which should be zero on every wall of a cube (kernel takes care of this boundary condition). More thoroughly my problem is to model ion flow in a cube by application of potential difference at left and right side of cube +1V and -1V.
Thank you.

So in Diffusiona and c,

you are missing the diffusion coefficient in both residual and jacobian
you add a ca and a cc parameter, but arent you using these kernels in the same equation as the diffusion term uses (eg ca = u or cc = u)
Are you even using them? in the input file you are using Diffusion, not Diffusiona or Diffusionc

@GiudGiud  as I made equation dimensionless no need of diffusion coefficients as I mentioned before. Also "diffusiona and c" are for corresponding "electroa and c" because here I have to couple variables.

Ok but diffusiona and c are not used in the input file. You have the regular Diffusion there.
if the equation is dimensionless don’t you need to have a factor on the time derivative ?

Earlier I used openFoam software in it program didn't run unless I gave
factor for time derivative but here it ran so i thought no need. Diffusiona
and c both of them are present in "electroa and c" Therefore I didn't put
it in input file.

Nishant Gaikwad-7972836355
M. Tech student
Materials Department
DIAT, DRDO,Girinagar
411025-Pune
…
On Sun, 25 Sep, 2022, 7:44 am Guillaume Giudicelli, < ***@***.***> wrote:
 Ok but diffusiona and c are not used in the input file. You have the
 regular Diffusion there.

 if the equation is dimensionless don’t you need to have a factor on the
 time derivative ?

 .
 You are receiving this because you were mentioned.Message ID:
 ***@***.***>

well if you want the right time evolution you will need to have the right coefficient in front the time derivatives. If you only care about the steady state, then it does not matter.
Ok I had not looked at the electroa and c terms. In those:

I also dont see all the coefficients in front of the gradient_psi term. This is once again because the equation is dimensionless I guess, but the factor is not the same as for the diffusion term
I dont think the Jacobian term is right. There should be an off-diagonal contribution given the involvement of psi, and the on-diagonal contribution should include grad_psi as well ?
If you want to post the derivation here we could discuss it

Thank you so much @GiudGiud  can i attach a paper in it on a particular page there is derivation of it and all. I don't have much idea about off-diagonal and on-diagonal terms. Please forgive me for 1 mistake I made "input file which I sent u is for uncoupled variables for diffusion terms in NERNST-PlANCK equation" Because I already tried coupling them & result was not converging anyway.
Sure I can take a look

jp402181e (2).pdf
Take a look at page number 4 and 5.
For electromigration term 👆 I tried soret wherein off-diagonal elements were computed.

Uploading VID_20220925_163421.mp4…
This linear profile should change & become more like exponentially decreasing but it doesn't change at all.

hello
the video didnt load. and please avoid pictures of text, they are not searchable by others.
The paper does not contain a derivation of the weak form, and of the Jacobian, so it's not helpful for debugging this.
If you want to check your Jacobian you can use the jacobian_analyzer python script.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/help/development/analyze_jacobian.html
Guillaume

Okk I will do so for weak form see equation (22) in following paper. But this paper doesn't contain any information about jacobian.
lu2010.pdf
Here is the video...

  
    
    

    VID_20220925_163421.mp4

Well exactly. The derivation of the Jacobian is the hard part, and it s likely where the mistake is.
Would you consider using automatic differentiation?
It's a lot easier to write the kernels that way
see this: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/modules/phase_field/FunctionMaterials/AutomaticDifferentiation.html

This is probably a better documentation page for AD
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/automatic_differentiation/#!
I d really advise it to get the Jacobian right

Yeah will go through this too if this works.

Nishant Gaikwad-7972836355
M. Tech student
Materials Department
DIAT, DRDO,Girinagar
411025-Pune
…

node.title: Problem about compiling the application
node.bodyText:
I get the following error in my application when I try to use make.
Strangely enough, I made it successfully at the first time. Then the following error occurs at the second compile.
(moose) wtang@tangw:~/project1/sma_eps$ make
10:01:29.201352 git.c:439               trace: built-in: git rev-parse --show-toplevel
10:01:29.440353 git.c:439               trace: built-in: git rev-parse --show-toplevel
10:01:29.479332 git.c:439               trace: built-in: git rev-parse --show-toplevel
Checking if header needs updating: /home/wtang/project1/moose/framework/include/base/MooseRevision.h...
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /home/wtang/project1/sma_eps/src/sma_eps_eieps2.C...
Linking Library /home/wtang/project1/sma_eps/lib/libsma_eps-opt.la...
/home/wtang/mambaforge3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/10.4.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: cannot find -ltcmalloc_and_profiler

Hello

Guillaume

Ok, the error is solved by modifying the format of #include to meet the new moose.
Thanks

node.title: Question about the PETSc options
node.bodyText:
I used a strange method to write a PDE which contains the variables of different blocks in Kernel.
But it shows Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_BREAKDOWN in terminal. I'm trying to figure out where the problem is.
I guess maybe the method is wrong or the form of the PDE is wrong.
I noticed there is a PETSc options -pc_type svd -pc_svd_monitor in NonlinearSystemBase. And it says "You can inspect the condition number of your preconditioning matrix for small problems (should be less than 1000 degrees of freedom) by running it". I'm wondering if this option can show the form of the PDE is true or false. I want to know if this can do what I want and how to use this PETSc option?

Hello
You pass these parameters to petsc_options_iname and petsc_options_ivalue in the Executioner block.
This wont tell you if the PDE is written properly or not, but it will roughly tell you if it's solvable. If the conditioning is decent, PETSc has generally no trouble solving the linear problems.
If you want to test if you implemented the PDE right you need to perform a verification procedure.
I ll paste here @hugary1995 's excellent suggestions from another post:
 In FEM code, typically two methods are used for the verification stage in code development

Patch test: You'll need to setup a problem that is as simple as possible in which the analytical solution is known, and the solution can
be exactly matched by the basis function of your choice. For example, you can create a single-element cube, apply Dirichlet BC on
 one side, and apply Neumann BC on the opposite side. By applying your kernels one at a time, you can easily match the numerical
 solution (given by MOOSE) with the analytical solution.

Method of manufactured solution: This method is documented here https://mooseframework.inl.gov/python/mms.html. In essence, you
 will first manufacture an arbitrary, non-homogeneous solution, and then work your way back to derive the corresponding "body force"
 that would result in the manufactured solution. Even if the manufactured solution can't be exactly represented on the basis function
 of your choice, you should still see optimal order of convergence by looking at the appropriate error measure.

Another concern is whether you implemented the jacobian right (did you use AD? If so dont worry about that part).
This page has resources for checking this:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/help/development/analyze_jacobian.html

Yes I've used AD. Thank you!
I think I should test if I implemented the PDE right first.

node.title: Materials in FV volume kernel

node.bodyText:
Hello
Functions and functors cant be access with []. Functions use .value(), functors use ()
We access functors by passing arguments, see some examples in Navier Stokes or in the framework.
A Qp, a face, an element or a position are all accepted arguments
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/framework/src/auxkernels/FunctorElementalAux.C
Guillaume

Ah, got you.

Thanks, Guillaume!
…

 Functions cant be access with [].
 We access functors by passing arguments, see some examples in Navier
 Stokes or in the framework.
 A Qp, a face, an element or a position are all accepted arguments

node.title: Error in ThreadedElementLoopBase dependent on number of nodes
node.bodyText:
Hi,
Sorry for all the posts recently about this issue, but I need to figure out why my program runs sometimes but fails other times.
Posts: #22033 #22287
I have no problems with compiling my project with a derivative size of 400.
I have a minimal input file that I use for testing.

3D rectangular mesh
The main variable, temperature, is set according to a parsed function to create a linear range across the x-axis.
I use NullKernel for temperature so there is no change.
My custom material property is coupled to temperature.

If I run the input file with

nx = 10
ny = 5
nz = 3

everything runs fine.
If I change it to

nx = 100
ny = 50
nz = 25

then I get
*** ERROR ***
We caught a MetaPhysicL error in ThreadedElementLoopBase. This is very likely due to AD not having a sufficiently large derivative container size. Please run MOOSE configure with the '--with-derivative-size=' option

I compiled the debugging executable and ran gdb with a breakpoint set on MPI_Abort. gdb returns this:
Stack frames: 21
0: libMesh::print_trace(std::ostream&)
1: moose::internal::mooseErrorRaw(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >)
2: void mooseError<char const (&) [219]>(char const (&) [219])
3: ThreadedElementLoopBase<libMesh::StoredRange<libMesh::MeshBase::const_element_iterator, libMesh::Elem const*> >::operator()(libMesh::StoredRange<libMesh::MeshBase::const_element_iterator, libMesh::Elem const*> const&, bool)
4: /home/cameron/projects/moose/framework/libmoose-dbg.so.0(+0x1002bd9) [0x7ffff55dbbd9]
5: void AuxiliarySystem::computeElementalVarsHelper<AuxKernelTempl<double> >(MooseObjectWarehouse<AuxKernelTempl<double> > const&, std::vector<std::vector<MooseVariableFieldBase*, std::allocator<MooseVariableFieldBase*> >, std::allocator<std::vector<MooseVariableFieldBase*, std::allocator<MooseVariableFieldBase*> > > > const&)
6: AuxiliarySystem::computeElementalVars(MooseEnumItem)
7: AuxiliarySystem::compute(MooseEnumItem)
8: FEProblemBase::computeAuxiliaryKernels(MooseEnumItem const&)
9: FEProblemBase::execute(MooseEnumItem const&)
10: FixedPointSolve::solveStep(double&, double&, std::set<unsigned long, std::less<unsigned long>, std::allocator<unsigned long> > const&)
11: FixedPointSolve::solve()
12: TimeStepper::step()
13: Transient::takeStep(double)
14: Transient::execute()
15: MooseApp::executeExecutioner()
16: MooseApp::run()
17: main
18: /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6(+0x29d90) [0x7fffeb699d90]
19: __libc_start_main
20: /home/cameron/projects/turtle/turtle-dbg(+0x3079) [0x555555557079]

Thread 1 "turtle-dbg" hit Breakpoint 1, 0x00007fffeba89820 in PMPI_Abort () from /home/cameron/mambaforge3/envs/moose/lib/libmpi.so.12

I also got the back trace, copied below:
#0  0x00007fffeba89820 in PMPI_Abort ()
   from /home/cameron/mambaforge3/envs/moose/lib/libmpi.so.12
#1  0x00007ffff67ecffe in moose::internal::mooseErrorRaw (msg=..., prefix=...)
    at /home/cameron/projects/moose/framework/src/base/MooseError.C:83
#2  0x00007ffff55742c1 in mooseError<char const (&) [219]> ()
    at /home/cameron/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/MooseError.h:256
#3  0x00007ffff556ef90 in ThreadedElementLoopBase<libMesh::StoredRange<libMesh::MeshBase::const_element_iterator, libMesh::Elem const*> >::operator() (this=0x7fffffffb050, range=..., 
    bypass_threading=false)
    at /home/cameron/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/ThreadedElementLoopBase.h:283
#4  0x00007ffff55dbbd9 in libMesh::Threads::parallel_reduce<libMesh::StoredRange<libMesh::MeshBase::const_element_iterator, libMesh::Elem const*>, ComputeElemAuxVarsThread<AuxKernelTempl<double> > > (range=..., body=...)
    at /home/cameron/mambaforge3/envs/moose/libmesh/include/libmesh/threads_pthread.h:380
#5  0x00007ffff557f4c9 in AuxiliarySystem::computeElementalVarsHelper<AuxKernelTempl<double> > (this=0x55555a006fa0, warehouse=..., vars=...)
    at /home/cameron/projects/moose/framework/src/systems/AuxiliarySystem.C:863
#6  0x00007ffff557eb20 in AuxiliarySystem::computeElementalVars (this=0x55555a006fa0, 
    type=...) at /home/cameron/projects/moose/framework/src/systems/AuxiliarySystem.C:789

    at /home/cameron/projects/moose/framework/src/systems/AuxiliarySystem.C:463

    type=...) at /home/cameron/projects/moose/framework/src/problems/FEProblemBase.C:3852

    at /home/cameron/projects/moose/framework/src/executioners/FixedPointSolve.C:424

    at /home/cameron/projects/moose/framework/src/executioners/Transient.C:329

    at /home/cameron/projects/moose/framework/src/base/MooseApp.C:1402
#17 0x0000555555557745 in main (argc=3, argv=0x7fffffffc288)
    at /home/cameron/projects/turtle/src/main.C:33

I tried to figure out what the error was caused by, but I had difficulty in understanding the back trace output. Do you know what it could mean?
Thanks,
Cameron

Attaching the input file would help.
Sounds like you'd want to define temperature as an aux variable. Then removing the null kernel should fix this issue.

I could attach the input file, but it is dependent on a custom material property I created. Could I send you both privately?
I did that and it can run with those settings, but I need it to be able to run when temperature is a Variable being solved with PJFNK.

So you said

I have a minimal input file that I use for testing.

I think we need to first make sure this "minimal input file" is a faithful representation of the actual model you will be running. For example, in your real model, you won't be using NullKernel for the temperature, and the NullKernel is probably the exact thing that causes the errors you see using your "minimal input file". In other words, do you see the same errors when you run the actual model? If not, there is no point in debugging this minimal input file.

I could attach the input file, but it is dependent on a custom material property I created. Could I send you both privately?

You can just attach the "minimal input file" and remove anything that you want to keep private.

In my full input file, I have:

Temperature with ADHeatConduction and ADHeatConductionTimeDerivative kernels.
ADMatHeatSource working with FunctionPathEllipsoidHeatSource and some parsed functions
a custom material property that provides specific heat, thermal conductivity, and density
a custom material property for crystallinity fraction - this is the part that causes problems
A porosity variable solved by a custom kernel
ADNeumannBC and ADDirichletBC
Full SMP preconditioning
Transient executioner

And when the mesh has 100 * 50 * 25 nodes, it gives me the error.
If I run it with 10 * 5 * 5 nodes, I get low resolution results that qualitatively appear correct.
If I try to run it without the crystallinity material property and with a high number of nodes, it runs fine. So that seems to narrow it down to this material property, which is why I thought I could isolate it into a more minimal file.
My minimal input file is not a faithful representation of the full model I will need. But I see the same error occur in the full model and the minimal model.
However, I can go through the debugging and back trace steps with my full model if you think that would be better.

Okay, thanks for the detailed information. Yeah, this is an odd one -- the MetaPhysicL exception is only thrown when the mesh gets large...
The only possibility I can think of is when your mesh gets more refined, the temperature and porosity variables get more resolution, and at certain quadrature point their values trigger the MetaPhysicL exception. You probably have log of a negative number or something like that somewhere in your material. Does that ring a bell?

Errr, now I see you got the same answer from @lindsayad in #22033
I don't think opening a duplicate post is a wise choice.

why is the auxiliary system returning an AD error though? in the backtrace
AuxiliarySystem::computeElementalVarsHelper<AuxKernelTempl<double> > (this=0x55555a006fa0, warehouse=..., vars=...) at /home/cameron/projects/moose/framework/src/systems/AuxiliarySystem.C:863
I d like to see smallest input file that fails

You probably have log of a negative number or something like that somewhere in your material. Does that ring a bell?

Log of a negative number and divide by zero were problems that I had before. But now I have bounds on my functions to prevent that from happening. Also, the debugger told me when I had those errors. Now, the back trace is more opaque.

I don't think opening a duplicate post is a wise choice.

I apologize, I wasn't sure if I should add to a thread after it had been answered. And I thought this may have been different enough to warrant a new post.
I did try what @lindsayad suggested and I got this:
Thread 1 "turtle-dbg" hit Catchpoint 2 (exception thrown), __cxxabiv1::__cxa_throw (obj=0x555562267210, tinfo=0x7ffff7f97190 <typeinfo for MetaPhysicL::LogicError>, dest=0x7ffff7f015dc <MetaPhysicL::LogicError::~LogicError()>) at ../../../../libstdc++-v3/libsupc++/eh_throw.cc:80
80	../../../../libstdc++-v3/libsupc++/eh_throw.cc: No such file or directory.


I d like to see smallest input file that fails

Here is what I can provide apart from the custom material property. I just don't want to post it publicly at this point, but I don't mind sharing it privately.
[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 3
  nx = 100
  ny = 50
  nz = 30
  xmax = 1e-3 #meters
  ymax = 0.5e-3
  zmax = 0.25e-3
[]
[Variables]
  [T]
  []
[]
[ICs]
  [functionIC]
    type = FunctionIC
    variable = T
    function = parsedFunc
  []
[]
[Functions]
  [parsedFunc]
    type = ParsedFunction
    value = '430 + 20000*x'
  []
[]
[Materials]
  [CrystallinityModel]
  (removed)
  []
[]
[Kernels]
  [nothing]
    type = NullKernel
    variable = T
  []
[]
[Preconditioning]
  [full]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  []
[]
[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = PJFNK
  num_steps = 1e3
  dt = 1e-5
[]
[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]

why is the auxiliary system returning an AD error though?

Could be material property aux.

I did try what @lindsayad suggested and I got this:

It looks like you were on the right track. You just need to print a backtrace and go up your stack to where the exception is being thrown
Don't worry about the No such file or directory warning

node.title: Feasibility in Random Vibration Analysis
node.bodyText:
Dear experts，
I've been trying to do random vibration analysis with moose recently，specific description is：apply an acceleration power spectral density function to the sample, under given conditions, through the acceleration PSD response curve of the test sample at its typical position.
I would like to ask, can MOOSE fulfill this requirement?
Thanks,
Krystal
@bwspenc  @cbolisetti

Hi @Krystalfang, currently, we can only perform response history analyses in MOOSE. Unfortunately, we cannot perform frequency-domain simulations (or eigen value analysis), which would be needed for RVA.
